posts.com: newfag here. Doing as much research as I can. Is breaking in a pipe necessary? I'm reading coating with honey and I'm thinking, back then, no one gave a single fuck and smoked the same pipe every day until it fucking was too caked to smoke. Is that necessary? posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2539255
Breaking in a pipe as any sort of long process is overblown.
For the most part, you can smoke a modern pipe from brand new without major issues.
When people talk about breaking in pipes, it’s about burning off whatever small wood fuzz is left over from drilling the shank and bowl, and charring the insides to make them flavor neutral. If you’re just smoking, it’ll take a few bowls for everything to settle down.

A lot of people like to smoke burley-based blends in their pipes while breaking in. This is because burley has fewer natural sugars that hold water in the tobacco. The tobacco burns a little hotter in the pipe as a result, speeding up charring. Smoking a few half-bowls also helps to make sure the ember gets down to the shank and chars that faster as well.

For most pipes, it should take no more than 4-5 bowls for this to be complete, and most cobs I’ve smoked are usually good by bowl 3.

I haven't been there other than driving through but if you want resort skiing, there's Schweitzer. I am sure you could find good backcountry downhill skiing (that would require skinning up or hiking up, or taking turns taking each other up on snowmobiles) but that of course requires having a friend, and both of you having avalanche training and avalanche gear. And I am sure you could also find good cross country skiing, but even if you're "cross country skiing" there could be avalanche danger, so if you don't know what you're doing, you should look for some maintained cross country trails (or go downhilling at Schweitzer).
In truth you kinda sound like a tard who would end up going into the backcountry alone and getting buried in an avalanche, so you should probably stick to in-bounds resort downhill skiing, or xc on groomed maintained trails (do web search "nordic ski area idaho panhandle" see if you find anything) until you become less of a tard

posts.name: Anonymous

>>2504957
>Im confused about what im looking for, do i want back country skis, touring skis, cross country?

If you just want to tour and are not interested in making Alpine descents then you want cross country skis. Specifically, backcountry touring x-country skis. They will typically be wider than fits in a groomed x-country track but they will/should have metal edges that handle a wider range of conditions and terrain- but they will still be double cambered so you still kick and glide like traditional x-country...this is the perfect ski for sking up ungroomed trails and forest service roads and exploring relatively flat terrain.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2519755
Those look alright. Shells are definitely the best option because of better temp regulation. Insulated pants are a no go during hot spring riding. I suggest you search sellers like evo, the house, backcountry, ect. They always have good deals and promo codes. You can get bib ski pants for around the same price as those. Bibs are way better at keeping snow out and have more pockets. They also fit and stay on better. Theres a pretty good deal on the north face freedom bibs on Evo right now.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2524069
Roundtop= go to the far left side with the double black diamond to avoid crowds. The center lift gets long lines.
Liberty= go to the backside but it'll be pretty crowded as everyone goes back there.

Honestly it's gonna be very crowded because it's MLK weekend and that's when everyone in the DC area remembers its time to ski. I had friends go to both recently and they have very shit coverage right now and might not be 100% open. I wouldn't waste time with a lesson your first day back, but after you get a couple days down, sign up for a "group lesson" midweek, and then when you get there it'll likely just be you and the instructor.

>What
Scott 81s

Snowbasin primarily but I visit Breck once a year to remind myself how good I have it

50-75 (I run a business seasonally)

Every area, I push hard every day, can't ever be good enough. I'm escorting my crazy son around a lot, he's getting so good, makes a dad proud as fuck. Fun to watch him work his way through a logjam of slower skiers, he's going to be better than I could ever dream of. Also he grabbed my backup boards a few ski days ago and adjusted to them instantly.

This is the best ski year in a decade. SB's base at 120" is officially in 'go everywhere' territory and it's a beautiful thing.

I'm a speed demon after getting out of the trees and my top speed is 76mph this year over on strawberry.

I'll be telling people about weekday skiing at SB when I'm an old man yelling at clouds. Can't take for granted having my own personal ski resort.

Trekking pole tents:
>very light
>generally good quality control (often made/sold by cottage companies)
>minimalist

Free standing tents
>heavier
>nearly always double layer
>generally more expensive for something decent

Both have advantages and disadvantages, and trekking pole tents often differ from one another. Some are single wall and some are double, some use one pole and some use two, and so on.

The one you posted sets up more like a tarp than a tent. It’s single walled and not very breathable, so condensation can be an issue. It’s also fairly small at 200cm (6’ 5”) long and 100cm (3’ 4”) tall. 20d polyester is pretty thin, especially for the floor.

Montbell makes great stuff but this doesn’t look too good.

>>2539114
I got to thinking about the tarp, bug net, and ground sheet combo and I thought of a few reasons why someone else might do it.

>as part of a modular hammock system
That’s why I personally have this setup. I hike in areas that are perfect for a hammock, but I took a trip to Big Bend and wasn’t going to drop a few hundred on a tent.

>a fun DIY project
A tarp is much easier to make than a tent. If you screw up a tent, it can be flappy or even leaky. If you screw up a bug net it’s not that big of a deal. Plus it’s fun.

>Europeans with few options
Am I wrong? There don’t seem to be that many European companies making ultralight tents.

>cheaper
Everything kind of ties into this, sort of. There aren’t many cheap, ultralight tents out there. And with a cheap tent, you have more possible failure point than a cheap tarp. You can find Chinese tarps and bug bivys on Amazon now, whereas maybe 5 years ago there were very few options. And they’re dirt cheap; I’ve seen them for $20. A decent nylon or polyester tarp from a reputable manufacturer is, what, $100? I know Dutchware has a bonded Xenon tarp for $135, which is like an ultra-premium new material thing that isn’t dyneema so it’s still moderately priced. Combine it with literally any $50 bug net and you’re under $200 and like 24oz, and that’s a huge benefit of the doubt.

You could probably do it for much lighter and cheaper. I just search and found a tarp by Boarh Gear, made in Montana. 70”x108”, $68, 7.2oz. Their bug bivy is 5.3oz and $84. So 12.5oz (354g) for $152 USD + tip (143 Euros).

>>2538437
I own 2 trekking pole tents: Black Diamond Distance and Durston X-mid. I also have an MSR Hubba Hubba (2-wall tent pole tent).

The trekking pole tents weigh less. Obvious benefit. The X-mid is 2-wall, with the benefits that go along with it (good ventilation, less condensation issues). The x-mid is kind of cramped in the inner tent though - you can fit your pad but that's it. There's plenty of room under the outer shell though.

The Black Diamond Distance is a single wall enclosed tent (think like a large garbage bag with a zipper) and has obvious condensation issues unless you pitch it just right against the wind. It's roomy inside, but the lack of an outer wall means all your gear goes inside, unless you want some of it sitting out exposed to the elements. Muddy shoes etc could be an issue. It's a tad lighter than the x-mid though. For some reason I really like it despite its flaws, and on several occasions have I found myself struggling to make it work, just because when it works, it's pretty good.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2510676
it's getting harder, but still doable
we lucked out a bit and found a 3.5 acre plot about 35 miles from town (western oregon), that already had planning permission on it. it's forest land, so the state/county was super picky about allowing SFD's out here.

the way we did it was to go through a building company (adair homes) and get a construction loan.
>land: 60k
>construction cost on the house: 130k
>site dev: 50k (grading/ excavation/clearing the firebreak)
>septic/well/etc permit costs: 15k
>down payment: ~25k

the construction loan covered all the costs, and upon building completion converted to a conventional mortgage. it sounds expensive, but after the build was completed the property was valued at around 500k, vs the 260ish we financed. You definitely come out ahead when building vs buying (and no PMI). Our mortgage now is only $1300ish out the door.

Construction loans usually have a 12 month term, at which point you need to have the entire project completed. getting through the county took 4 months, and that was with the permit already in place -- otherwise it would have been a year for that approval alone. TL;DR plan on buying your land in cash, then hold off on taking out a construction loan until you know you'll be able to build (there's some obvious risk here, buy the land and the county could just say "no, you can't build here, for reasons".)

All this was done on 2 middle class salaries (135k household income), but that's kind of the minimum in 2022 to even buy a house, period. (which is a terrible omen of things to come in the US)

This is all assuming it's actually rural.. closer to town the price of land increases enough to make it profitable to parcel out tiny mcmansion yards.

But all that is assuming the county would even allow it, oregon for example would almost certainly cock block that (planning goals here are basically designed to preserve farm and forest land.) Trying to develop formerly productive farm land into a SFD is going to take literally years, LUBA (thanks landwatch) proceedings take forever (assuming you win.)

If you had actually gone through the process of a build, or developing land at all you'd know it's not nearly as simple as you make it out to be.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2532012
How much does a horse cost?
It's a complex question and will very much depend on what is the minimum you can live with and what you are willing to DIY. You say plug ins. Does that mean you want a grid attachment? In most places they'll only grid attach buildings that meet the code.
Before you get attached to the idea of grid, see if your needs can be met with a portable power station and a few solar panels. If you only use a low power laptop it's more than enough.
You say no insulation. But what about vapor barrier and sheathing for wind? How about windows? If you can 100% DIY and are comfortable living in a shed then the cost of an A-frame would be the cost of a chainsaw and a small amount of metal roofing from facebook marketplace or similar. You can get leftovers from other people's bigger projects for cheap.
If you want to learn conventional framing with 2x4s from the box store and put it on a concrete pier foundation like those used for sheds or outbuildings, and you wanted it finished with a typical shingle roof and vinyl siding, you're probably looking at north of 20k in materials cost.
Again though, it really really depends on what you are willing to learn, how much time you're willing to spend, and whether you are stubborn enough to do things 100% on your own.
If you want some inspiration watch a video on:
- cordwood construction. This is a method of building using cheap dry softwood logs as bricks in a DIY lime mortar. It's a niche technique here in the north. It's commonly used by single-family DIY teams that value a low-cost house over a low-labour house. It takes a lot of time to lay the wood bricks and for them to dry.
- shelter institute timber frame construction. This is a typical modern timber frame. They build with simple joinery but it would take a good amount of practice for a new framer to learn to maintain his chisels and cut the joints properly. The lowest labour finishing technique for these houses is to use SIPs.

>>2537001
Real estate (Royal Estate) is permission to use the Royal Estate. In the US, this nearly always means land incorporated as a municipality. You don't own real estate. The municipality does. They can therefore force you to pay tribute (taxes) as well as services (utilities) regardless if you use them or not. This is also why any hook ups are owned by the city and not the deed owner, and why there are innumerable ordinances specifying what you can build and how. Many municipalities disallow you from, for example, living in an RV, even in the middle of fuck nowhere. You have to instead build a house that is hooked up to their entire system and pay for it all, which is all fine and good so long you know what you're signing up for.

>>2535371
Been there for a few days. Such an odd sight from a plane, at times there'd be nary a sight of human activity visible at all, just endless forests with clearings and swamps scattered in-between, all the way to the horizon, lost in haze. Sometimes there'd be a road visible. Once or twice there was an ugly patch of landscape where oil was being drilled, looked like the kind of pattern bug parasite larvae leave on the inside of tree bark.
I stayed in a small town. The living conditions were more or less on par with what one would expect there, but supermarkets had pretty much the usual stock. It was summer and the weather was nice, not too hot. The river was too chill for my liking but I can't stomach any that isn't borderline tepid anyway. Didn't go out much, the locals warned about about bears wandering around stockpiling fat for the winter already. Didn't have any issues with mosquitoes though on other occassion I met a photographer who told me about his experience in a different area and month, according to him the air was teeming with them. Their group all wore hats with nets hanging off their brims and whenever it was time to eat, they'd briefly lift the edge of the net to let the spoon through, a few mosquitoes would make their way in. I forgot to ask about repellents.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>2539100
Poison oak, gotcha. I hate that shit. I took a look around the internet and the only thing I found with a lot of reach is a Christmas tree trimming saw. You can order them from forestry supplies websites. I've never used one so I have no idea how heavy or tough they are. But essentially it's a saw, and if you decide a saw will work then I'd just buy a lightweight trimming saw. I've annihilated blackberrys with mine and I'd definitely use it for poison oak if push came to shove.

The only other thing I can think of is an Old Hickory 10" butcher knife, but it's a little on the short side for serious poison oak destruction. It is, however, very lightweight for a 10" knife, and you could fashion a long handle for it easily: remove the original handle and use wingnuts to secure the new, much longer handle to the tang. Good luck.

Chickens are an amazing animal to keep around. They are like a barn cat in many ways.
First off we can eat chickens and there eggs, and that's cool on its own.
Secondly if you have a proper plot of land chickens can survive by scratching with little to no supplemented feed.
This is a big one the keep pests down, tick, lady bugs, even snakes can be keep at bay by a good flock.
Lastly all the poop is a good fertilizer.
In short if you have land chickens can be a low maintenance self sustaining food and sanitation solution.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2532155
Only slaughter them after a LONG time (8 years) unless you have some kind of efficiency operation going. Like if you dont have multiple roosters, so that you make more chicks for free, then dont slaughter them like that. You can at the end of their lives slaughter them and make chicken soup or feed them to your dogs/cats (very healthy). Hens lay fewer eggs as time goes on but yeah you dont want to slaughter them needlessly like that without a breeding or efficiency operation. If its such a big deal to have 2 fewer eggs per week then just buy an extra bird.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2535338
For better or worse the geography of the USA makes it very difficult to build mass public transit like you see in Europe. Cities and towns are much further apart, many, at least in the west where I am, are outgrowths of large mining claims which means they are inherently in more complicated geography than Europe and Asia. Approximately 20% of the population of the USA lives in "rural" locations compared with 8% for Japan, in Germany only 6% of the population lives more than 25kms from a large population center. Running the cost benefit analysis, its hard to justify. I'd love to take the Amtrack from where I am to Western Warshington, but the nearest large city to me is 45 mins away, its a 7h train ride, and its a 5 hour drive in a car, and that is with only a handful of stops in eastern Washington. If public transit services the small towns between here and there (as they would have to, for it to even be useful to everyone a public transit) that would add hours in just stop time. And this is just for a short journey between Idaho and the Washington coast.

>It was made for someone to carry combat gear while wearing other gear, not to comfortably carry and sensibly organize a expedition's worth of things

Some military packs can be very organized. And for more than just lugging shit load of combat gear. Take an alice for example. All those pouches. Certain places for certain gear. And don't forget that sometimes soldiers have very little time and a lot of shit to do in that time. If you can sit down behind it and open one or two pouches and feed yourself in 10 minutes, without moving from that spot, while never touching the main pouch where your sleeping gear and clothing are until it's time to use them. That's great for anyone imo. They're also huge yeah, you don't have to fill it up. But to replace where you might have inside main pouch a big old radio and a bunch of machine gun belts with extra food and water. You can go a long way with one. People love to say the things are old and outdated but I just call it proven. I can tell you I've been in a light inf unit where we got new age packs given to us and quite promptly everyone decided it was a piece of shit and demanded the alice back, because the new thing was basically 2 big compartments, and other crap like straps breaking etc.

>>2532922
>they have one problem: waist straps, not hip straps

You'd find most soldiers that patrol with one on cut off those things anyway, because you really don't want to be stuck to a 100lb pack when someone starts shooting at you. You want to drop the thing asap

There is actually some modern takes on these packs made but they cost about an arm and a leg, but if sounds interesting look up MALICE pack. Or really you could make something quite similar with a few old surplus packs and a sewing awl

It REALLY depends on where you live and what you do. Here in Washington state it's a lost cause and it's more important to focus on being comfortable in the rain over attempting to be dry. I just use a normal rainjacket and a rain hat with a bill, which really helps keep my face drier. But if you're stuck in wet weather here it doesn't let up for days. posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2538685
>to stay completely dry in rain
That is a lost battle before it begins. If you go with full waterproofing condensation will get you, if you go with membranes it will be a bit better but only as long as DWR coating keeps up with shedding water. Long story short, the more you isolate yourself from the external moisture, the more you produce your own. You will never be completely dry, just accept that. On the other hand, at least for me it seem anything completely waterproof (PU coating, rubberized stuff, whatever) loose enough to allow some air to blow underneath is good enough, a poncho, an oversized rain jacket, hell, you can make a tarp cloak if you want, all works. You will get the splatter, no escaping that, but (again, in my experience) as long as you can keep your head, neck, torso and feet comfortably not-soaked you will be fine. Also, wide brimmed hats work amazingly well if waterproofed.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2539268
If you have your layers right it doesn't matter much, i personally believe in one item - one job. Thermal layer is to be warm but breathable as much as possible (also helps if you have to sleep in it, you don't wake up all disgusting and damp), waterproofing is to be as waterproof as possible, does not have to offer any thermal properties. even if you get some cold gusts under your rain layer the thermal layer should make it a non issue.
This is the reason i don't like all those "all in one" swiss army knife of a jacket things, they can do all the functions well enough if properly designed and maintained but will never match the comfort of split function layering. The other advantage of splitting the jobs is flexibility, if the day is warmer than expected there is no issue taking one thermal layer off, if it's dick freezing off cold you can put every last piece of clothing you have on and still fit that rain layer over that.

it's about building codes/minimum standards for dwellings more than anything.

i'm guessing mostly it's the fact that jurisdictions haven't really caught up to living offgrid. there really should be a variance for these types of dwellings. if someone wants to buy some land and build their house, install septic, etc etc on their timeline, that should be their right. no one is going to buy a fucking house on a plot of land and then realize "oh shit, it's not on the grid, fuck me, i didn't bother to see if there was electricity!"

like my county (lane, OR) has minimum dwelling sizes, septic/mains/well requirements, etc etc; which make it either outright impossible to buy land, and build a homestead from scratch, or make the permitting/siting process take so long that construction loans aren't feasible. For example: getting a conditional use permit for a dwelling on F2 land requires at least 18 months of paperwork and waiting around while some 25 y/o nitwit planner looks for reasons to deny your build, meanwhile construction loans typically have a 1 year conversion timeline. wife and i lucked out and found a property that already had the CUP on it, otherwise there was no way we could have swung the land purchase and rolled it into our construction loan.

it's such a fucky situation, one that a lot of the naive 20 somethings here completely fail to understand. then again if it were as simple as rolling an RV onto a plot of land and going for it, there wouldn't be any countryside left. Some states are probably more amenable to this kind of thing, but the overall trend seems to be to make moving out into rural areas more and more difficult -- environmentalism gone wild coupled with a subtle/backhanded mommy government hatred of proles and independence.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2505999
Sure.

We do seasonal pigs here. That is, we purchase feeder piglets from a local farm in the spring, and then they go to the butcher in the fall. We do this specifically to avoid overwintering pigs and dealing with full grown breeders. It's a lot less work on our part and we don't carry the burden of the breeding stock.

Because of this we have a 1.5 acre forest pasture rich in acorns for the pigs to live on. They shop up when they're young and easily handled. Already cut and weaned. We purchase pig feed from a local feed mill that has very reasonable prices and sources somewhat locally. Pigs handle the feed well and grow quickly. We only usually need to deworm them once during this process. As the weather is mild they generally don't need much housing. They destroy anything you give them anyways, so their run in always looks like shit.

We keep 2 for our family and sell the other 3+ which pays for all 5+ pigs every year. Essentially we 'eat for free'. We sell half shares of pork to friends and locals who buy into all the buzzwordy meat stuff. This is why they go to a butcher, because there's some regulations there on how meat sales and preparation are handled. I send my two along as well because our butcher does a much much better job than I do and the pork sales cover it 100%, so why not.

People want to eat meme breeds so Berkshires are very popular, but hybrids are generally more vigorous and less likely to fail to thrive. Berkshire crosses is what we generally handle here.

In a small operation, this is the most cost effective and easiest method by far. Every year we look into buying a male and two females to start our own breeding program. Planning on keeping 5+ piglets and selling the rest, but the cost of everything skyrockets and piglet sales alone won't cover all the costs, so the operation starts operating at a loss and my goal is always to break even on food.

>>2510634

What does intellectual pursuit mean?

I have plenty of time to do whatever I want. Sometimes when I'm out doing chores I'll listen to audiobooks, especially if it's just splitting firewood or digging post holes or something else I can sort of tune out and enjoy the semi-meditative nature of the work. I read books before bed.

We can our own hides for buckskin and furs. My wife sews things for me and the kids like moccasins and wool clothing. We spend the winter months doing quiet things around the wood stove indoors. This time of year the days are so short and the outdoor work is really at it's lowest point we have plenty of idle time.

Summer is just busy as it can be. I routinely work sunup to sundown without much of a break. Unless you count the 9 to 5 as a break. There's gardening, animals to care for, chickens to hatch, firewood to log out and stack, always something needs fixing, or some animal in distress or whatever. Usually summer is the worst time to build things and run fence. That's best left for spring/fall.

There's plenty of time to do all manner of things. You just have to do them differently than you might expect. I don't have time to play video games much anymore, but I don't particularly miss them either.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2510648

Yes. There's plenty of time to do all of these things. You can attend university online, if that's what you want to do with your life. The pandemic put higher education on the internet for two years, and it's still running that way if you want to go the more traditional route.

I can find anything I need on the internet. I have the opportunity to get a Masters for free, and I can do it all via remote learning. Though, in my case, most of the classes are 'read two books, write a paper, read two more books, write another paper' style courses. I just have to do the paperwork to get started, but an advanced degree really won't affect my lifestyle or career at all, so I'm not in a rush.

I don't particularly see the point of any city. They're massive ultra consumerist shit holes. They produce absolutely nothing of value. They survive off of an infinite number of trucks constantly pouring in filled with goods produced elsewhere. I haven't voluntarily set foot in a major city in nearly eight years and my life is better for it.

If you live this lifestyle, it depends on how you live it. It's different for everyone. That will determine how much 'leisure' time you have. If you're really shitty and lazy you'll be too busy fixing your own fuckups to have much time to do anything else. But, if you're earnest and honest in your work and do it right the first time and never procrastinate or half-ass anything, you can have a lot of good down time to enjoy the fruits of your labor.

The lifestyle is also very seasonal. You'll be very busy in Summer, but very very not in Winter, assuming you did everything right. Now is about when I enjoy a full freezer and pantry and catch up on movies I missed during the year.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>2510832
My grandparents had a farm and were farmers. They were retired when I was a kid, so I spent half the year out in the country in the middle of a farm community basically left to my own devices. I then read Hatchet and My Side of the Mountain and the other mandatory out books and it made me obsessed with camping and backpacking. I spent as much time outside as possible and had an aptitude for the farm chores and outdoor lifestyle.

I grew up, went to college, got a good job in the city and resigned myself to living the good urbanite lifestyle until I met my now wife. We both started hanging out and slowly realized with BOTH hated living in the city and wanted to live out in the woods and raise sheep and things of that nature. So we just left. Now we have several children and are making the homesteading thing work.

Resources for homesteading is a tough one. Nothing will ever be a stand-in for hands on experience. Most youtube videos are charlatans if not outright liars and I've actually somehow ended up helping out a few IG homesteaders with things like all their chickens dying from easily treatable illnesses that opened my eyes to how much the influencer crowd is just ignorant if not outright malicious.

I'll go through my homesteading bookshelf later, after I put the boys down for bed, and see if anything jumps out at me. Five acres and independence is a good book. The figures are out of date, but the concepts and ideas are timeless.

I did some googling and the initial results seem to quote $5000-$7000 USD per hectare (2.5 acres) for Argentine farmland.

I'm not particularly surprised by roughly ~$2400/acre for farmland in Argentina. Things like local laws, government taxes, access to global capital, exposure to foreign companies, etc. means that you, an Argentine, may be competing with Monsanto or some New York holding company for the land.

The USA still has tons of cheap farmland because A) it's a huge empty country, B) rise of urbanization means tons of prior-farms are abandoned or sold dirt cheap, and C) the economics of agriculture incentivize for certain commodities to be produced locally and then sold to a major processor or middleman (ie. Purdue chicken).

Sorry to hear Argie bro. $2400 USD / acre is a lot harder for you than it would be for somebody from the USA.

posts.com:
>>2507191
Yea keeping pigs ain’t always easy, financially speaking. I worked on a pig farm for a year during the onset of covid (in which it was eventually shut down due to pig prices plummeting), so I can speak on a few things.

Sometimes you’ll get a sow who after a 114-day gestation period births 16 piglets. Sounds great. But you have to consider some of the piglets die right away since they are worse than runts and can’t survive a day. So you’re down to 13. Then after detailing (literally cutting the tails off, otherwise piglets at 2 months will begin to bite the others, once there is blood, watch out!) you’ll have to give them proper shots to ensure their survival till market weight. During all this, you better make sure you have farrowing cages, otherwise the sow might accidentally roll over a naive piglet or two while she positions sideways for milking, or even worse yet, she may indulge in infanticide which is common with pigs. It happens even with farrowing cages, but much less so than without them. There will also be piglets that randomly die of unknown causes, so that further complicates things if your looking to profit.

When it comes to breeding, unless you are running a decent operation, keeping a boar around will prove costly for the fees needed, but also the upkeep like shovelling his shit every day or two. Also a boar will lose potency if not bred constantly. One sow every 200 days or so ain’t enough. I would probably just go for AI (artificial insemination) at that point. No boars, no rearing them. Just need fridge space.

Overall I think what you described (raising 5, selling 3 to “eat free”) is probably the best bang for your buck. I’m currently clearing a bunch of land for a terrace to grow some vegetables and friut trees. I might just buy 5 small pigs and let them run around in there and fatten them up. Sounds much better (natural) than actual pig farming lol

I’m still very early in the process anon, but I’m basically trying to revive my grandfathers lands, where my family has been for over 100 years. So there’s very much a feeling of being engrained with the land, and wanting to make the best of what I have in order to benefit me, my animals and my family.

We have about 5 acres right beside the house. 2 acres are right up beside the house, we usually just let our horse chill there, but we have partitioned it before to plant sweet potatoes, beans etc with great success due to the sunlight. The rest of the acreage lies below, most of it again is just mostly flat (with some slopes) pasture for the horse/cows, with a random lemon tree in the middle lol.

There is a part (picrel) that lies in a “grota” we call it in Portugal, that is home to about 4 orange trees, a bunch of other fruit trees of the Goyave family, and some wild yams. I’m personally trying to improve things first by cleaning up the entire area. There’s a bunch of weeds, invasive trees, and just general overgrowth that has appeared as the product of neglect. Once that is rectified, I will try to terrace and till some of the parts of the sloped portion. The flat part below will once again see banana trees, as had once been the case. We had to remove them since they are very laborious and need someone there year round to tend to it.

Great thing about where I am is that it’s December 27 and it’s 17 and sunny out, so a perfect time to do all this stuff before planting season, which for my area is February. I have a bunch of other ideas for chickens, pigs and other animals that I may elaborate on later!

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Good thread bros but I feel like some of you guys are making a simple mistake. Being self sufficient doesn't mean having ALL your food and resources come from your property. That's impossible and it never worked like that in any point of human history.
The way they did it and we should do is have a main source of income (e.g. farming crops) and small side farming for your own use (chickens, a couple of cows, pigs, etc). You use your main income to sell and trade locally with your neighbors for whatever you need and the side stuff guarantees a good share of your nutrition.
If you're smart about it you don't even have to have huge land and wait years for your crops to be ready for harvest. For example a small 150 square meter barn can house 1000 laying chickens. They're laying eggs every day and you can butcher the old ones.
Another example is honey bees. It practically doesn't matter the size of your land since bees don't give a fuck about fences and will use all the land they have to feed. I mean of course you'll still make a sizeable initial investment but it may start praying for itself almost instantly.
Yeah it's not epic innawoods off the grid hermit but you get to that point after at least a decade of preppring anyway, so no sense in trying to go directly to that.
Now post homestead channels and waifus.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>2523907
Give yoursef 2 acres of woods for firewood, replant every tree you chip down. Get 2-3 cows, cycle them with either a bull or artificial insemination at different times of year so you get milk year round. You’re gonna want 3 acres of pasture for this. Keep it grass. On your last 2 acres, build your structures and use it for plants that you yourself will consume. Parta that you dont eat can be used to feed poultry or pigs. If I were you, I would buy a piglet every year and raise it for slaughter. You can let it supplement off pine cones or acorns and such in your woods. Take a quarter acre and grow corn to feed the pig. Take another quarter acre and put a pond on it, this is really important because you can periodically excavate the bottom layer of the muck and combine it with compost juice. The water in your pond can also temporarily fertilize your garden or your cow’s pasture. Try and srock your pond with fish that are able to attract and kill and eat insects. Attracting Insects for food should be your pond’s top priority, since insects cone from outside your property, and are thus an infinite source of food. Archerfish are my favorite but I dont think they necessarily breed. You want a fish that breeds more of itself. The fish themselves can be good winter sources of protein and bone nutrients for poultry.

My wife drives to the beach every sunday night and picks up a truckload of seaweed. We use it for poultry feed and compost. If you take an acre or so every couple years and leave it almost fallow, but with a twist: Plant a deep root plant like dandelion and let the roots go deep into the earth. Eventually you’ll want to root up all that dandelion so you can plant grass or some other plant. Well, here’s what happens: the dandelion will grab nutrients that have sunken far into the warth, below where your plants can get at them, and now you will be able to turn those dandelions into fertilizing compost to place back on the topsoil once again.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2534722
>people that I know in Southern BC manage to grow Mandarin Oranges by using plastic covers and christmas lights during the few truly cold days
Those are for the (very scares and few) days there where it dips in the 20s. Those parts of BC are a europe type maritime, very mild climate.

In northern Canada OTOH, deep in the center of the continent, you’re running a whole different ballgame. -40 degrees is just a whole different beast. My opinion is that you will have to grow your fruit trees inside of a thickly built greenhouse, with lots of thick brick or stone walls and thick glass, perhaps with some kind of built in heat blanket to come over the top during those polar vortexes which you’re gonna get and which will kill your plants. If I were you, I would invest in gas heating technology alongside a wood burner to heat the thing.

I’m not trying to demoralize you, just laying out the facts of what you should expect. Are you planning on keeping any cattle? Did you know that new technology permits us to harvest the gasses released by cows, and turn them into fuel? This is also possible with compost- capturing the gasses released during decomposition and storing them. I have seen hippy communities in Costa Rica successfully implement this technology. I think the cows might need a surgical operation for this machine to work though, IIRC. Not sure. That might set yousome kinda logistical limit since you’ll be so far out.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2534944
Zone 2 sounds damn hard. No personal experience, but a few things you can do come to mind.
Earthworks, walls and hardy shrubs and trees that shelter from prevailing winter winds are crucial. Kinda like a horseshoe shape, open to the south, closed to east west and north. Will also catch the sun in spring and warm up faster than flat land would. Extra points for big rock piles that act as thermal batteries.
For a nursery, you can dig trenches that you can cover up in winter. Below soil level will stay slightly warmer and may safe your young trees.
If you dig a bigger whole and put a glass roof on, you got a walipini. If it's big enough, you can put a couple trees in there too.
If you can get an excavator in for a day or two, that should be enough to prepare all these earthworks pretty fast and for not too much money.
Also look into passive solar greenhouses. Particularly from the rocky mountain permaculture institute. That's a little more involved and expensive, but would probably allow you zone 7 plantings inside. They grow bananas and figs up on a mountain in those things.
An attached greenhouse at the south of your house is also a very good idea. Gives you an extra layer of insulation for your home and the greenhouse profits from your heating. With some lights, you can probably grow winter greens continuously and extend you season enough to grow a couple proper tomatoes.
With all your greenhouse options, you can add a woodstove imbedded in a big thermal mass (brick or cob), that you can fire up in the worst parts of winter.
With all plants that overwinter outside, mulch them heavily for frost protection. Like 30cm+ straw, leaf or sawdust. You can also wrap stems and branches of your trees in straw and cloth.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2535352
Forestry is a good start. Depending on the type of land, you might need to clear space to make it useful. You'll also need to clear brush and other fuels to prevent fire. Some of what you learn will depend on what you want to do. Do you want animals? Start learning about how to care for them, how to fence them in, and related topics like how to manage grazing without destroying your land. A lot of homesteaders seem to go all in on doing everything by hand, and I guess that's fine if you've got the time. Personally, I have a full time job as a software developer, so I can't afford to spend hours every day manually weeding and dragging around hoses. We have taken some ideas from commercial operations and we use woven ground cover cloth and drip tape in our gardens. We're still using organic fertilizers, but it gets injected into the drip system. I also make several yards of compost every year. We also got a tractor, which saves shit tons of time every year. My point is, start thinking about the style of gardening you want to do, and build the skills to support that. Also, learn some basic construction techniques. You might not be planning on building your own house, but being able to put up a storage shed or animal shelter will be invaluable.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2539280
>In terms of keeping me fed
You can't do this out of a garage, let's assume your garage is an average size of 260 square feet, you can even double this size if you have a really big garage.
An acre is 43,000 square feet. You need at least 900,000 calories a year. Do the math.

In a garage space you could grow lots of high-value stuff like lettuce, herbs, and other small plants but you'll never get calories from such a small area for more than a few meals. Those leafy greens and herbs also grow better under grow lights than calorie-heavy crops like potatoes and corn do, grow lights only really work well for greens that are inherently low-calorie.

You COULD try to get some strawberry setup and get a decent yield of strawberries to sell / trade other people for more valuable things, some countries plant their strawberries in gutters, harvest them, then move the plants into coolers to force them to start growing more berries immediately, either that or herb selling would be your best bet for such a tiny area.
And yeah, mushrooms (both the drug and the food) are also high-value and if you just dedicated a whole garage to them and sold them you would make a decent amount of money.
Calories are impossible for small indoor areas.

Bayous in Louisiana aren’t stagnant. Not sure if that matters in the definition. Colloquially the words bayou and swamp are used interchangeably, and sometimes man made water ways are referred to as bayous (but never as swamps). The same goes for wetland and marsh; I don’t know if there’s a technical difference, but we use the words interchangeably. Generally “wetlands” is used in a broader scope, like “save the wetlands”, while marsh is more specific; “my hunting camp is surrounded by marsh.”

Anyway, Louisiana’s bayous, swamps, marshes, and wetlands are terrible and never any fun. Don’t come here, ever. Trust me, it’s bad.

It's not a polygon based map, it's just centroids based on named locations using the selected keywords.
Since Minnesota has fewer uniquely named wetlands that are larger in size, it gives the false impression that there are barely any wetlands in Minnesota.
It's interesting that Wisconsin and Michigan apparently have multiple named bayous though.
Also interesting that Texas and New Mexico don't have any named coulees even though there are absolutely plenty of features that fit the description, but those states weren't historically settled by French-speaking populations so they are called otherwise.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2535391
The map was setup to go off of official place names. So anything named "swamp" on a map would get a pin even if there wasn't a real swamp there. There are wetlands in UT, NV, and AZ and the rest of the southwest but they are mostly associated with seasonal or permanent marshes, ponds, springs, and creeks. Examples in AZ include Mormon lake, Wilcox playa, perennial and seasonal river and creek oxbows and sloughs, hundreds to thousands of natural small ponds and basins that flood in spring snowmelt and during monsoons. Utah likely has even more examples.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2533003
You don’t necessarily have to leave empty spaces but your options are limited. It’s something I deal with every year. You can either A:
>start your seeds in containers then transplant them after your spring/summer plants are done
Or B:
>only allow your current plants a certain amount of time in the garden
For example my fall plants (planted in September) only have 5 months to produce what they will and then I will pull them up soon to start preparing the space for my spring garden, but I also do some combination of the above where I only pull some plants when their time is up.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2533057
Experience mostly. Come up with a plan of what you intend on growing, how long it takes to germinate an estimate of when it will be to harvest. And strategize your planning around that. While you can't plant summer plants in spring, you can absolutely plant spring plants throughout the entire growing season ( I plant lettuce, arugula, carrots, kale, etc) all season long. With proper care, variety selection optimized for summer you can have lettuce and whatever the entire season. In order to do this you have to practice succession planting (planting a crop succesively every week or two to have continual harvest) You also need space to do this and an ability to crop rotate (when this plants coming out I have a new plant taking it's place.) Most summer crops happen to be fruiting plants (tomato, zucchini, etc) that are plant and done till they die from disease or the cold. So what I do is dedicate entire beds to my summer plants and work my spring/fall specific plants around that. I have two rows dedicated to trellising plants (tomatoes, cucumbers, pole beans) i intercrop determinate tomatoes with my climbing beans and bush beans with my climbing tomatoes and cucumbers. I have a row for peppers which I can intercop things like lettuce or radishes, whatever you want that doesn't take up to many nutrients. My garden is 8 30inch rows 45 feet long atm and when you map out an entire planting strategy my summer beds automatically rotate themselves to spring planting beds by next grow season. Draw diagrams of your garden space, figure out what you're planting and the harvest time and ask yourself if I want a continual harvest of something like carrots or lettuce what do I need to do to achieve that, where can I plant them, where can I plant my next row of them, etc. It requires very thoughtful planting but it's not hard to figure out the optimal strategy for your alotment

>>2534634
A single stake isn't a great idea, raspberries spread underground and send up canes all over the place. Raspberries can be a pain to grow in that regard. Usually I see people grow them up against trellising or use a Florida weave sort of set up to hold the canes up.

At my place we have a dwarf variety of raspberries instead though. The canes grow to ~50cm in height so they just end up looking like normal bushes when developed. Don't require much support, and if any is needed can just do stuff like put in a few stakes and tie thread around to make a basic cage to hold it up.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2534652
I've never specifically done barley, but I did do oats in a raised bed once. Definitely possible and not to difficult to grow, harvesting by hand sucks the biggus dickus though.

Canada says average yield for Barley is 65 bushels/acre, so assuming you can manage a similar amount of attention that a farmer does to a much smaller plot, you'll need 670sqft/bushel, or 17sqft/lb. So a 5'x3' bed will give you less than a pound of the stuff.

A quick google search suggests that you 2-3lb of barley for 5 gallons of beer. So if you wanted 5 gallons, you'd need to plant at least 34sqft of barley.

Seems pretty reasonable if you have some space, honestly.

posts.com: Thinking of doing microgreens/sprouts, likely daikon radishes. Already looked up a few ways to try to grow them but wanted to see if any anons had a preferred method.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2535601
old glass jar, gauze bandage and rubber band.
i use a table spoon of seed in old 720ml pickle jars. put the bandage on the opening and keep it in place with the rubber band. fill jar with water and let it sit for 30 minutes, then pour out the water. (gauze keeps seeds in jar).
then put the jar upside down at an angle that allows fresh air to enter, but all excess water to drain.
every morning and every evening you fill the jar with luke warm water, swish it around a few seconds, drain the water and place it as described above.
place the jar on a window but not into direct sunlight.
do this until harvest.

braindead simple and works flawlessly every time.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2535608
>avoid cleaning husks
when harvesting, get a big bowl/pot fill it with water and then move the harvested material around a bit. the majority of the husks will collect on the side of the bowl and you can just lift out the green stuff. not everything will be gone, but it doesn't really matter too much anyway. you don't really notice them while eating and you should use seeds specifically sold for this purpose to prevent them being treated with nasty stuff.

>getting a bunch of crap to automate watering
if you do the method with the old jar you water it in the morning and in the evening (or twice a day when it suits your rhythm). that's 10 seconds of effort each. don't overcomplicate things and don't spend money on pointless gadgets. old pickle jar, some gauze bandage and a rubber band is all the equipment you need.

daikon radish is a fine starter i suppose. the sprouts have some spiciness, but not much really, and they taste fine. so go for it.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>2536464
One thing you can do is look-up the weeds growing in your yard with an app like iNaturalist. They'll tell you what kind of soil you have. What you basically need to worry about when starting out is drainage. If your soil is compact it won't hold water or worse water will puddle there and drown your plants. That's most people's first problem. Then you have to site a bed for light. Building soil is easy you just have to be patient. You make a big pile of organic matter and let it decompose and then spread it over your beds. Ideal soil is "spongy" when wet with enough critters and microbes in it to help your plants uptake nutrients and keep things balanced so pests don't devour them.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>2536598
Heh my lemon post in the now-404d plant thread hasn't received any attention either. Considering taking that elsewhere and turning it into a blog-like thread so that it stays longer and increases the likelihood of either someone learning from it or giving advice without the need to repost.

Background: family has been growing vegetables since forever, most of them would start out as seeds in a moist towel while the world outside would still be covered in snow - and I've been around to partake in the process, but none of these plants were of citrus variety, so there's plenty of unknowns. Besides, they'd always end up being replanted into the ground removing some potential issues from the equation.
What little experience I have with citrus, all comes from these lemons and I wouldn't say it's been going without a hitch either. That said, here's some thoughts:
—Citrus are best grown from cuttings (at least lemons are) but it's definitely possible to grow something out of a seed too, otherwise there wouldn't be any so keep at it.
—Seeds are whimsical, in general. Healthier plump-looking ones from mature-looking fruit have the highest chance of sprouting into something decent but to give an example of how it has worked out for some of the seed-grown saplings that I had had, out of 10 or so, only 6-7 properly sprouted, then 1 or 2 perished after barely having surfaced, which left me with 5, of which 2 were very ill-looking. Half a year later one of them just withered away, the other still clings on despite not having advanced in its development since like July. All of them shared nearly identical conditions, though some had slightly different soil mixes or pots. Your bottom left (red pot) looks kind of like the one that died on me.
—Looks like citrus seem to prefer potasium-rich soil. Compare your soil's composition (written on the bag) with citrus-specific one. Probably too early for that but there's special fertilizer you have to feed them too.
cont

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2536598
>>2536634
—I think heating mat did help mine when they were placed on the windowsill, though the bottom parts of pots felt too warm for my liking and I had to raise them a bit. Currently moved them a bit further away from the windows and am supplementing them with electric lights instead.
—Depending on your latitude, days may be too short, may want to invest in a grow lamp (or just a regular lamp and a bright e27 led bulb, preferably with a specific spectrum recommended for plants)
—Generally just watering the top layer of soil isn't enough, you want to make sure the soil is soaked all the way through. I'd water them gently, until water starts leaking through the bottom holes, once every 3-5 days. Think I used to do it more often when pots were smaller. The soil has to dry out between the waterings to prevent potential rot or those stupid mold flies, but drying out too much is also bad.
—Probably not your case but just leaving it here for future reference: looks can be deceptive, if you carefully dig your finger a few cms into the soil and it's dry even though you've just watered the pot that means you have the same problem that I did where some parts of the soil have compacted and won't let water through so it always drains down one side. You can notice it if pouring even a tiny amount of water results in it leaking out from the bottom. Usually happens after you haven't watered the plant in too long. In my case I carefully dug around a small depth breaking down any lumps I could feel and trying not to damage roots, then mixed the perturbed soil with some fresh one, pressed it down a bit and watered it a few times repeatedly then emptied the saucer.

Also if one were to perish I'd probably not reuse that soil, maybe it's gone bad. Better get some fresh one, preferably for citrus. Soil needs to have bacteria in it, they're not immortal, so old dry soils need to be mixed with fresh lively ones.
Probably forgot or missed something but oh well.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2537537
Remove the tops of the shoots down to the last pair of leaves, so that all of the outermost shoots have a single pair of leaves left.
Use what you've cut off either in the kitchen or to make new plants by putting them into a glass of water for 1-2 weeks until they grow roots. Then they go into soil obviously.
Ideally, the pruning as described above should be done whenever you harvest (never harvest by plucking individual leaves off a shoot) or on a regular basis during growth.

Personally, I'd toss that plant and replace it with a cutting of itself.

Also, if you want to get as many leaves as possible you should grow as many plants as you have space for. Don't forget regular pruning as described above.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2537878
https://youtu.be/ohjK6gqYBNc
This guy lives in Southwest Colorado. He has some great tips. The gist of it is mulch and compost. You have to build soil by composting and then you want to keep the soil covered with plants and organic mulch all the time so things don't dry out and die and get lost to the winds.

Also if you're growing peas well but nothing else really grows your soil might be lacking nitrogen, so you might want to look into planting nitrogen fixing plants to use as green manure. They have bacteria in their roots that take nitrogen out of the air and put it back in the soil, so you can just chop and drop the aerial portions of nitrogen fixing plants to build soil the slow and old fashioned way.

>>2536206
heimlich is for when the person cannot talk, cannot breathe, cannot or can barely cough, and is still conscious.

if they don't meet all the above, and they're still conscious, you basically just pound them on the back until they cough it up

but if it's real small, like a sprig of parsley or something, then just drink water until it clears itself.

you can do a "self-heimlich" if you're the one choking. you just throw your lower abdomen repeatedly at a desk/chair/whatever while driving a fist into the space between your rib cage and navel.

if they're unconscious you're recommended to do CPR. 30 bone-crushing compressions to the beat of "Stayin Alive," 2 breaths. if you feel that your compressions wouldn't be painful, you're not doing them hard enough. 15 firm compressions (use fingers only) for infants. You shouldn't just crush a toddler because they passed out; they're squishy and you can do more harm than good if you treat them like an adult.

most countries have some version of a "good samaritan law." the idea behind such a law is that you're not allowed to sue someone for trying to help and failing to help. most countries do not have an "obligatory aid law." it's uncommon, but in some regions it is illegal to withhold aid if it would not harm you to provide aid. quebec is an example of a province that has obligatory aid in their legislation.
>although I don't know of any examples where obligatory aid charges were pursued by the Crown

>>2532097
>Permits
You can buy them for $20, buck tags are extra
A cool thing about the PA hunting license is you get year round access to state game land ranges, and you can bring one unlicensed guest. I go to range 203 all the time.
>Guns
Depends on what you are shooting. I use a cheap double barrel sawn down to 20" with target load for squirrels. My typical engagement distance for squirrel is less than 20 feet. If you know somebody that grows fields of feed corn, ask if you can hunt there. In fall/winter the squirrels will come out of the woods to drag cobs back to their trees to eat. Look for where there are more corn cobs and corn scraps out of place in the woods around the bases of trees.

I shoot woodchucks out my bedroom window with a suppressed SBRd AR15 with CMMG 22lr conversion bolt and subsonics. Engagement distance for me is less than 50 feet. Not really "hunting", more like pest control, but I do eat the groundhog that I shoot

30-30 is pretty standard for deer here. This was my first year hunting deer and i didnt get anything but was with people who did. Set up in a stand an hour before sunrise and a couple hours before sunset. If you are with a bunch of other guys you can "drive" the deer in the daytime into eachother. Have one group form a horizontal line each 200+ feet apart and have them walk at least a half mile towards another line of shooters. Wear orange, obviously. Use terrain to your advantage, like pushing deer into a corner like the bends in a river/creek, use the high ground, etc. Also look for where bucks grind their antlers on trees.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2532097
Consult wildlife officials for the most accurate information, as well as your state's official website. Some states administer online training courses, others require an in person class. I would suggest going through your education course, then picking specific game animals to hunt. I would personally start with squirrel and rabbit, as they're small game yet have traits akin to larger game animals. Squirrels are very very tough, hard to process as a beginner, and their hides make an excellent challenge to tan and craft with. Rabbits are the opposite, you have to be as careful as possible on thin skinned rabbits. I'm based (kek) out of Missouri, where our small game seasons end on the 15th. We're currently late season, so the animal movement has been slowing down quite a lot. But learn your target game's psychological needs, reproductive habits, shelter types, calls, hours, etc. Squirrels are active in the morning and the sunset, while rabbits are also primarily nocturnal or operate within the morning or sunset. Squirrels nest in dreys or in holes in trees, while rabbits bed in thicket or crevices. Can do an improvised squirrel call using nothing but 2 US quarter dollars to imitate the sound of a nut, or can buy a critter call that sounds like them. I would suggest trying to hunt with an air rifle or slingshot first as it maximizes opportunity due to noise, but really any hunting weapon will work. .177 air rifles are an excellent beginner's shooter, I'd look into Gamo air rifles. Lead ammo is your best bet as these do not kill by penetration, but by blunt force trauma. You will most definitely have penetration, but if you have a super fast round pierce a squirrel and exit out the other end, you may instead just maim the poor fella. As of late I have taken a liking to slingshot hunting as well, using 7/16" steel rounds. Ultimately for both, what kills small game is accuracy. You're going for headshots only. Hitting vitals may guarantee a kill, but(cont)

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2537461
These small animals are FAST and they may very quickly run to a shelter in which you cannot retrieve them. I would suggest setting a specific distance goal, such as 5 or 10 yards, and practicing on your desired weapon. For squirrels, their head is extremely tiny and moves a lot. You want to be able to shoot a ping pong ball at least 7 out of 10 times on average. You owe that to the game animals you're killing, as well as to the community. Legislation on air rifles and slingshots is steeped in dumb misinformation, the last thing we as hunters want is to continue that trend. I would practice this daily until you're capable of these feats, and then prepare yourself for your hunt! Camo is not a requirement, but it certainly helps a lot. I have found that solid greens work quite well too, but camo seems to yield the least amount of unsuccessful stalks. Scent control is also not a requirement, to me personally it feels like you're going all out if you're genuinely using it for small game hunting. Animals usually know you're there, but just being aware of the wind direction tends to aid in making yourself invisible. Something I haven't found mentioned many places either is that squirrels often seem to not react too much while eating, which to me(I'm not an expert on animal psychology) seems rather counter intuitive... For them. For us, it usually gives a unique opportunity to eliminate them as humanely as possible. I have yet to observe this behaviour in rabbits, but they're usually either standing still or sprinting fast anyways. I do apologize for the long post, but hopefully this gives just a little bit of insight, best of luck!

posts.com:
>>2532097
There's some excellent info from knowledgeable hunters in this thread. I'll add a couple of things. First, expect to get grossed out and frustrated when cleaning game. Use a really sharp knife and know how to resharpen it. Kill a squirrel or rabbit and haul ass home to clean it; it's better to learn how to clean one animal at a time so you don't have to worry about spoilage. Eventually you'll learn the tricks of cleaning fast. Don't expect everything to taste as mild as chicken or beef. Most game has a wild flavor, and some (like antelope) can turn your stomach if you don't know what you're doing. You'll be surprised at how good some small game tastes - squirrel and rabbit in particular. So, try to keep the animal cool if you're not going to clean it in the field, use the appropriate tools to clean it (game shears are a thing), and know that the animal will look a lot better once it's cooked, even if it's a whole squirrel skewered on a stick and roasted over a fire.

As far as useful things to take hunting, just take what you'd normally do for a walk in the woods or fields, plus maybe an old cotton pillowcase to put the game in before it goes into your daypack. Other things like how to actually find the game and not get lost are skills you'll learn as you go along.

One final thing: Always be sure of your target and what's beyond it.

>>2520224
I grew up in a village in germany. Germany is a pretty urban country, and as a result most forests are pretty "tamed". But it was plenty in the eyes of us kids.
Our main motivations were that it was essentially a big playground without supervision. No parents, no strangers, just us. It was possible to play in many ways (play with softair rifles, or dig trenches, or build treehouses, or shelters) that you simply didn't have the space for at home. The biggest draw was the feeling of adventure. We'd climb under the electric fence where sheep were held and pet them (sometimes they'd let us sometimes they'd attack us), then again under it back into the forest, we'd sometimes "steal" honey from some beeskeeper (he knew, but he also knew we wouldn't take much, so he let it happen), we'd search for treasure, go in places that were forbidden (a old mine and a forest bunker were favorites) and sometimes we'd go looking for animals. Always hoping to see deer or a hog, but usually having to settle for some frogs or squirrels instead.
>And also what was the best thing or THINGS you did there?
I have the fondest memories of building shelters. We had "bases" in the forest and inside those we stashed our treasure - stuff we had found. The coolest among those were WW2 leftovers, we had found a ammo box, something that may have been artillery or a mortar round, thankfully not live, and a lot of animal bones. Other than that, fighting with sticks, exploring the mine and the occasional hog encounter.
>>2520359
>at what age would it be safe to turn your kid loose to go play in the woods?
Once they can be trusted to know their boundaries and the risk of the forest around them. It really depends on the forest though. I'd say we were "fake alone" by something like 6 (as in thinking we were alone when parents actually watched/were nearby in emergencies) and really alone around 8.

where i grew up, we'd often play in the river (hunting snakes/crawdads in the summer). posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2520477
>the tendency towards safety mommyism might actually do more harm than good
I 100% agree with you. Some freedom, and that includes the freedom to fuck up, is needed for kids to become adults. But some risk is also unneeded. Getting hurt playing in the woods and either fixing it with friends together or going back home injured is formative, hitting the rusted WW2 artillery shell with a stone to see what's inside may have ended badly.
I still remember the very first time I went somewhere alone:
I was very young and my parents allowed me to get bread from the bakery alone on a sunday. It involved walking down 3 streets, crossing a small intersection, going into the store, ordering, paying and going back. I couldn't do math yet, so I had no idea how much I had paid or gotten back, but I remember how proud I was when I got back home. Years later I found out I never was alone - my father had followed me with a camera to see if I would cross the intersection carefully, avoid any traffic and be alright on my own. Once he knew I was fine, he knew I could be trusted to leave the house alone from there on.
I think the way they did it was best: First a pilot run, where they kept me safe but I could feel like I was alone. Then once that went well, they let me do my thing. That way they could trust I was fine on my own and I could be free of parental control.
Your main goal is avoiding the shit that can result in death or severe injury, for the rest, it's better if they find out themselves.
We had plenty a injury from homemade fireworks, fighting with sticks, etc. Kids learn surprisingly quickly to take care of each other.
Either way, don't stress about it too much anon, you sound like a great parent. Listen to your inner fears, then rationalize how probable they are. If they are unlikely, allow your kids freedom. If it's reasonable, air on the side of caution. You got this.

Used to love that show.
I lived on a big property surrounded by woods, the closest road being dirt and gravel and the nearest neighbors a ways away. Didn't have internet or cable tv so when I wasn't reading books I went outside. Always wore either flip flops or rubber boots. Mostly I played in mud puddles, catching frogs, turtles, lizards, etc. Loved to make forts. I knew our property and the surrounding woods like the back of my hand. Surprisingly I've never been in actual danger, the worst that I can recall is a big strange dog growling at me but that happened right in the yard, and two trespassers coming onto the property to steal scrap metal. I had to run through tall grass back home to tell my parents. I saw snakes and black widows often but had enough sense to avoid them. Stupid thing I did was walk onto a froze over pond despite not being able to swim, also wading into a creek that got pretty rough. Hope this is what you wanted to hear OP.

I groed up in a small New England farmtown. My parents own several acres of woods but the entire forest is maybe 2000 acres (and that's just 2000 acres contained by the road, the woods continue semi-forever).

I spent every day in the woods as a kid, all day. Just about never once saw another human being anywhere in the forest or on the hills. I know those woods like the back of my hand - you could show me a cropped photo of a rock or a stump or even a puddle and I would tell you where it is. It was amazing.

>tree climbing
>foraging wild apples and berries
>building forts and treehouses
>camping out (as I got older, as we have significant problems with burr and coyotes)
>"woods training" (basically our kid version of forest parkour)
>following the old stone walls through the woods looking for old artifacts
>over the years found an old two-man saw blade, some hand-forged horseshoes, a whiskey bottle from 1870, an axe head, an iron jaw trap

parents still own the property but things are changing, parts of the woods have changed hands and development is encroaching :[

>>2520224
I grew up by a forest. I think I walked every path every day every summer from when I was old enough to walk until I had a job in high school.

It was nice. The quiet lets you collect your thoughts, feels good to breathe the air, it was calm with the exception of the occasional other kid or family hiking through.
>the park was preserved by the city, so it didn't shrink, but there's a highway on the north side, high-density housing on the east, and ever increasing intensification on the remaining sides, so it's no longer quiet
It was fun to tell jokes, or stories, or just look for critters. There used to be a lot of raccoons and bats there, but now there's not a lot. Sometimes we'd build little teepees or shelters. But the park staff would yell at us if we got caught, although I suppose there was no real repercussions.
>I walked my parents' dog through the forest a few months ago
>some kids had built a lean-to and were shooting some kind of drug
>I phoned the park building, they seemed annoyed I had bothered

The forest has a lot of hills. If you're not paying attention you can just step off and fall down a 45+ degree incline until a tree stopped you. Well over a decade ago, I remember some friends and I were screwing around, probably just telling jokes and being useless like usual, when one of us tripped and fell down the biggest hill the in the forest. He was just covered in bruises the next day, probably hit every single root and stone on his way down.

Nothing really happened there that was "the best," but I remember loving my walks with my dad. No real events, just wasting time with dad and trying to catch fireflies in the park on the far side of the forest where it opened into a field. Maybe the druggies and dirtbags were always there, but I only remember him explaining things like the pine trees leaking pitch because of the beetles, daring me to climb the trees that mum never would let me, lying to me about how fast a runner I was, etc.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com: How long could you last innawoods if society collapsed whilst you were camping?

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2525955
best almost everywhere: merino wool nylon blend
best in hot+humid weather (florida etc): thin coolmax synthetic
really fucking rainy places (pnw etc): thick coolmax synthetic

avoid 100% wool imo. the lifespan is too short and its wasteful. when you blow holes in 100% wool socks they're done for, whereas with nylon blend ones you'll still have the nylon mesh the wool's attached to in tact to hike out on until you can replace them.
consider stronger mixed natural fiber blend socks if you're one of the anons who doesn't like synthetic fibers and want to fully avoid them.
wool alternatives: alpaca (hypoallergenic, non itchy, bit less durable) bison down (more durable + better thermal properties) muskox (similar durability, best thermal properties) and angora (best-best thermal properties but can only be blended in small %s because fiber is very short)

posts.name: Umbrellanon
posts.com:
>>2527985
My man!

Short answer: yes.

But! Umbrellas are very situationally dependent. Sometimes they’re absolutely the best option, and sometimes there are better options out there. If there’s a lot of wind driven rain (and I mean a lot, not just a slight breeze in a light drizzle), you might be better off with a jacket. If the trail is really over grown (basically bushwhacking; a little overgrowth won’t hurt anything), then your umbrella may get snagged too often.

Where they work well is light to moderate rain. Just as a rain jacket is paired with pants, an umbrella can do the same. They also pair well with a very light jacket, such as a water resistant running jacket. That combo provides heavy protection from rain via the umbrella while the jacket keeps any blowback from soaking you, and it’s still more breathable than most options. A lot of thruhikers are using this combo now. It’s pretty versatile; if it’s not raining too hard you leave the jacket off and use just the umbrella (unlike just a rain jacket, where it’s all or nothing).

Breathability is a huge umbrella advantage. It’s why it’s the absolute best rain protection in hot environments during rainy summers. In the South, rain showers spring up out of nowhere, and dissipate just as quickly. They’re so scattered that raining while the sun is out is fairly common. A jacket would leave you very hot and sweaty.

It doesn't have to be a months-long expedition to qualify as /out/. Even day hikes qualify as /out/. posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com: What are some ways I can attempt to predict the weather conditions for the next hour or two just by my eyes?

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2533248
How far can you see? If you're in a steep sided valley you won't see the thunderstorm until it's on top of you. But generally, high cirrus clouds indicate good weather. Birds will head for the nest as bad weather approaches. Sudden cold wind in the summer means a cold storm approaching.

The best you can do is to learn the climate of the area you're in. For instance, the Rockies typically get a thunderstorm in the afternoon during June and July. Don't tempt fate by going out woefully unprepared. Get in the habit of looking up and around for approaching storms. If you head out on a perfectly clear morning and start seeing clouds in the middle of the day, that's your clue that a storm might be coming. If you're below treeline you might not care too much but it's always good to keep an eye peeled.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2534419
>Do trekking poles lower energy expenditure? started to see younger folks using them and trying to figure out why
They're basically useless for anyone under the age of 60, with the exception of mountaineers at very high elevations. In high-altitude conditions, your oxygen-starved body simply doesn't work the way it should, even after acclimation, and of course you're ascending or descending relatively steep slopes.

For everyone else, they're a stupid trend. Photos and videos of mountaineering have always existed, but really exploded in the 2010s after GoPros, selfie sticks, and monetized YouTube really took off; famous sponsored mountaineers such as David Lama even started bringing camera crews with them.

Tourists and day hikers saw all these professional mountaineers using trekking poles, wanted to be just as cool (heh) as they looked, so now every last zoomer and yuppie uses the damn things, and in recent years gear manufacturers have been making tourist-grade packs with trekking pole storage loops, tarps meant for trekking poles, etc. (These tarps aren't for mountaineers, you know, due to the fact that gale-force winds will rape a tarp straight off the face of a mountain).

They even imagine that the trekking poles help them hike/ascend better, will swear by it, but this is a placebo effect slash justification for their mountaineer LARP.
