posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com: Last time i went to zion I stayed at the ponderosa ranch resort on the east rim, they have basic camp spots for about $25-30 a night, nice showers and free breakfast, the Observation Point hike is nearby, certainly less crowded than in the canyon.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com: Should be early enough to avoid massive crowds, though Zion starts to really become a shit show late April. If ur camping snag spots now or be knowledgeable about where the BLM land is for boondocking (Gooseberry Mesa is nice near Zion). Obvious free sites can get pretty crowded. Would definitely recc the full Peekaboo/Queen’s/Navajo loop at Bryce, really cool rocks. Snow has been insane this year in Utah so I bet the river may be too fast to do the Narrows in April, but that’s also maybe the most touristy part of the whole park, so whatever. Worth doing once tho, but you’ll need the gear, as it’ll be cold. Zion Rim trail is sick. Angels is a shit show constantly. Used to love it, but it’s a mess and permits aren’t helping. Bryce is pretty high up so it’ll still be cold fyi, probably 20s at night in April.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com: How bad are the crowds there? Ausfag hoping to do a big trip in June/July/August, probably Zion in August.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2536140
Zion: All of the popular trails will be jam packed then, and getting in and out of the park will involve a lot of waiting. If you want to drive from one end to the other budget 3 or 4 hours because boomers clog up the tunnel with their RVs.

The wait times for the shuttle to the trailheads on the bus route (closed to private vehicle traffic) will be long. If you do try the popular hikes, Angels Landing for example, you will be continuously walking around groups taking selfies, the whole way.

Bryce: Similar but less busy and easier to get in and out of.

My advice is don't go to any of the big NPs in the busy season. Except Big Bend and Guadalupe where it is too hot during those months for the casuals. Failing that just accept that getting in and out will suck and if you drive finding paring will suck, but once that is done you can walk off into the backcountry and have a reasonably OK time.

If it were me in that area at that time I'd skip Bryce and Zion and the Grand Canyon and go to Vermillion Cliffs.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com: if you can get a reservation, I recommend doing the top-down overnight trail at the Zion narrows. It's a private company that takes you up to the top and drops you off with all your gear and you just hike down, i think it's like 13 or 16 miles, I don't remember. But you avoid all the crowds coming from the park and instead go down the river. It only gets crowded the last 3-5 miles because that's when most people turn around if they started going up. Very refreshing and beautiful in the peak of summer because the river is cool!

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2535848
Zion: the tent campgrounds in the park are nice. You're a five minute walk to the buses that ferry you into the park. Observation point requires you to drive out the east side of park to a small parking area in blm land. Park by 0700 to secure a spot. There is enough room for dozen cars or so. Easy hike to observation point after that.
If you start your days early it's not too bad. Zion is hell after Memorial day. There are some cool slot canyons east of Zion you should look into. I can't remember the names but underrated. Springdale sucks except for the hipster coffee shop near the park entrance. great spot to enjoy a morning with a great view.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>2536271
A bug net (often called a bug bivy when they’re shaped like this) can be setup under the tarp. Without one you might get snakes and you’ll definetly get a lot of bugs crawling in your lips, up your nose, in your ears, and snuggling in your sleeping bag with you. Pic the the Mountain Laurel Designs bug bivy but there are a bunch of companies making them.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2536271
Don't camp next to south-facing slopes, where the critters come to sun.
Don't camp next to big flat rocks under which they can hide.
Screen your campsite carefully for burrows and the like.

i present a new concept: sit camping.

this is also good for innawoods shit because you can immediately react to a threat.
